body: @lucperkins My feeling is that this is should be a command line helper rather than something in the fqn. Thus I would vote it to be removed from protobuf, even if that means that in the config file, we need to specify tenant/namespace/name
@srkukarni I feel like FQFN should be settable either via the command line *and* via YAML or neither. Inconsistent interfaces will likely sow a lot of unnecessary confusion.

In that case, I'm now questioning the viability of having this feature. Having tenant/namespace/name AND fqn clearly pollutes/increases the surface area unnecessarily imo. @jerrypeng @sijie do you guys have thoughts on this?
Thanks @merlimat , make a mistake here. will close this.

@merlimat , Thanks.  From the test logs, ownership acquire seems not take to much time, but loadNamespaceTopics takes some time. 
The linked list is a concurrent link, seems work-able in test, maybe there is some race condition that not considered.

Currently `FunctionConfig` is used  for 1) stored as part of function metadata, and 2) loading yaml config 2. That means this question has two parts:

1) do we need FQFN for function metadata
2) do we want user to be able to configure FQFN in yaml file?

I think it is clear that we don't want to store FQFN in as part of function metadata (which I think that is the original purpose of this change).

for the second question 2), I think FQFN might be convenient on command line, but not very sure about yaml file.

I am ok with users specifying functions via fqfn but currently FunctionConfig already has tenant, namespace, and name fields.  Adding another field fqfn would be redundant and create multiple sources of truth which can easily result in bugs later on.
@merlimat - here the WIP for PIP-11. Can you check if this is what you were thinking? If so, I can continue in this direction.
retest this please // ManagedCursorTest.cursorPersistenceAsyncMarkDeleteSameThread again (passes locally) & c++ test timeout
@rdhabalia Please take a look as well

> Thanks. From the test logs, ownership acquire seems not take to much time, but loadNamespaceTopics takes some time. 

That is correct. `loadNamespaceTopics` will take some time even if the topics are already being loaded because it would fetch the list of topics (this would be then cached),  and go through the list to try to load them. 

If we use the CompletableFuture, that should be solved anyway because we can complete the future and then load the topics in background. But the operation will be only triggered once.
I'm going to close this for now and potentially re-open at a later date. I don't envision working on this within the next few weeks. Best to keep the backlog clear unless necessary.

I think the underlying issue here is that using a Protobuf definition as a source of truth for configuration management is an anti-pattern in itself. At some point we should strongly consider using a more native approach.
@lucperkins I have discussed with @sijie @srkukarni, we are going to create another class for functions that is user facing and the FunctionConfig proto will be the internal representation.

Seems the assignment is balanced well. for a 3 brokers cluster, and a 128 bundle namespace, each broker will got assign 38,36,39 bundles.

Yeah, I had hoped to take a look yesterday evening but fell asleep. Looking now. re: example under "test", I honestly didn't look, I copied an existing example so I could run an end-to-end test, I will move it.

@sijie circling back on your tutorial comment, I merely added some more files to an existing set of examples. I agree that this should not live under test but in order to keep like things together and to isolate changes I propose we leave these new files here and submit a new PR to move the tutorial files to a different location.
@merlimat I've standardized the versions used by both modules. Please take a look again. Thanks!
managed ledger closed test failed. seems like a flaky test. rebased to latest master.

> * When we attempt to create the producer, we should validate the schema this producer is about to start sending is compatible with the last schema we have in store, otherwise the producer should be denied.
> * Same for consumer, if the type is incompatible we should fail the consumer creation.

This will have to happen in the broker. At this very moment I have zero idea what it means for two JSON schemas to be "compatible", this will take some additional research.

> * We should have tests to do basic operations on the JSON schema, eg: get the schemas for a topic, delete, create, update

fair enough

> * We should be able to have a check to control whether schema is enforced or not for topics of a particular namespace.

"check", do you mean a config parameter?

I suppose I could hack in a default "is compatible" check that literally checks if they are equal which would require schema updates to happen via the REST interface. This would make upgrades hard/impossible to do seamlessly.

> I suppose I could hack in a default "is compatible" check that literally checks if they are equal which would require schema updates to happen via the REST interface. This would make upgrades hard/impossible to do seamlessly.

I think for JSON we should first check if there's a schema and if the schema type is the same as a starter. For evolution, I guess the basic check would be to validate there are no type mismatchs. 
It's typically ok to add/remove fields (provided we have configured Jackson to do so - and we should verify that), but changing type would lead to errors in deserialization.
@sijie We should probably update the docs in `./site/docs/latest/adaptors/KafkaWrapper.md` to mention this artifact as well.
@sijie Thanks for the comment, updated and rebased.

I don't fully understand the logic of the test, but the delay in the callback is based on a random sample which is probably the reason of the intermittent failure. Can you take a look when you have the chance?

@bardock Skipping messages from that ledger should solve the issue. 

In particular you can get the internal stats for the topic: 

```
bin/pulsar admin persistent stats-internal $TOPIC
```

This should have the info on how many messages were still not acked on that ledger. I think the TTL is not working there because it's trying to read few of the messages to check the timestamps.

For the skipping part: 

```
bin/pulsar admin persistent skip $TOPIC --subscription $SUBSCRIPTION --count 1
```
